title: Wednesday, 13th February 2019
bodyHTML:
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Morning.

Blank canvas morning everyone
VV75 morning
BE11:09am

Hello, welcome, hi. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily whatever thing.

Soundbuy Hello
DogDay morning
A. M. morning all.
BE11:11am

.... And that short pause was the CMS logging me out ten seconds after logging me in.

PBateman Morning
Finlay Morning...I was wondering if the delay was an attempt to scare us into submission...
11:12 am
BE11:12am

Right. Back. Okay, total professionalism as always. How are we going to pass the time today?

wayneJ Morning
Soundbuy I won't mention Smurfit..........
BE11:12am

There's Brexit and cardboard boxes and Digby Jones.

wayneJ Would a good start be the Ineos contribution to the debate on regulation?
BE11:13am

There's the odd bit of sellside, such as a Merrill thing on how everyone's after the lunch of Asos and Boohoo.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

And Credit Suisse on Rolls engines, which now seem to be working better.

wayneJ Poor Digby confused how 'the will of the people' does not apply outside of UK territory. Presumably it is like shareclasses - with Digby believing that UK voters have a supervoting class that imposes its will on the EU and all other countries / politicians?
BE11:14am

And Tullow and maybe Galliford, if we really need some DPL.

Flaneur 'Final' Brexit will be delayed until 2020, by which time Russia will have invaded so it'll be moot....
DJ Morning
BE11:15am

However, let's start with yesterday.

11:15 am
Plus500 Ltd (PLUS:LSE): Last: 1,148, up 15 (+1.32%), High: 1,149, Low: 1,064, Volume: 1.62m
Finlay @WayneJ...oh, the irony of those moaning about EY tyranny trying to impose their will on other nations....
BE11:15am

Up now, was down at the open.

Flaneur (@BE - surely Countrywide for the DPL?)
DJ I hope Plus500 creeps back up to 1500 so we can all short it again

The press coverage of yesterday's warning wasn't as critical as is could've been.

red @ DJtested 1200 and fell which was the first hurdle. think 1330 will be best you see before falls again.
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Here's Lex, for instance, pointing out that directors sold and so on.

BE11:17am

https://www.ft.com...-8744-e7016697f225

red a lot will depend on how mkts perform this year as to how much they can claw back, but given regulatory environment, they are never going back to the high margins days of past
DJ @red yeah but it's very heavily shorted so could get squeezed
BE11:18am

The stuff about betting against its own customers comes up towards the end.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The surge in revenues in the fourth quarter was entirely down to customers’ bad bets, coming amid wild market moves.

That flattering of profits looks unsustainable. More worrying is the implications for the stability of the business. Plus500 has always said it made its money from spreads, the difference between the price at which customers can buy and sell, plus any overnight interest charges. The statistics bear that out: profits from its customers’ losses were just 3 per cent of revenues over five years. But behind that figure is a lot of volatility. In 2018 there was a gain of $172m; in 2017 a loss of $103m. That suggests a weaker quality of earnings than thought.

BE11:19am

Okay, sure, turns out earnings are worse quality than thought. That's bad. But how bad?

BE11:20am

I'm indebted to a reader for highlighting this bit of the Plus June18 prospectus.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

BE11:21am

Okay, so gains from prop positions were marginal as per June 2018 and by yesterday they were more than a third of pretax.

DJ @BE that's interesting. I guess that means that either (i) Plus500 takes a position which could go horribly wrong or (ii) matched trades don't move the market price
BE11:21am

What happened there then?

red majority of their clients are noobs and lose all their money. thats a kind of visibility in that once they acquire client its just a question of time.
Pharma @BE, is that actual highlighting, with a real highlighting pen? How quaint.
hornblower any chance of the summary on the research note on ASOS. ex CEO now has pledged 100% of his shares for a margin loan. Now below £29, getting close to price where he has to sell shares. or boats or houses
11:22 am
BE11:22am

2018 prospectus says profit or loss on customer trading positions amounts to "a marginal component of the group’s overall total revenue)" and "in each of the financial years (17, 16, 15) . . there were no net gains for the group." ..... Curious.

BE11:23am

Anyway.

undefined
Excel Developer Is USA inflation set to take off (in 11 months time)? US Small business selling prices lead CPI by 11 months according to this graph, https://twitter.com/IanShepherdson/status/1095303184376123393
VV75 Osram just on tape, PE interest apparently
wayneJ @Finlay - there was a really nice analysis the other day on twitter of the 'growth markets' that are driving future growth - which is the brexiter argument to leave the EU - #1 and 2 are China and India; #3 is EU and the US is #4. I seem to remember a certain home sec blocking an EU - India deal. And as for the US - a certain Wilbur Ross is recommending US co.s take advantage of Brexit....hmmmm
red the fact that they were not hit at all by swiss franc move should have told you how it operates if you didnt know already. morally questionable possibly, but a great business model
11:23 am
BE11:23am

@Hornblower wants Merrill on online. Yes, to a point.

FATDAZ @hornblower seem to recall one of the carphone warehouse guys got himself in a mess using leverage loans vs his stock holdings back in the day
Electric Dragon @Pharma, looks like Windows Snipping Tool, where you can take screenshots of part of a window and draw freehand on it with a "highlighter pen" among other tools.

Here's the summary I've just written of it for elsewhere.

hornblower @Flaneur - Countrywide numbers and pipeline look pretty good in the circumstances
DJ @BE everyone is dying to know how your highlighting tool of choice
Pharma @Electric Dragon - thanks. The things they think of...
BE11:25am

Merrill Lynch downgraded Asos to “underperform” and cut Boohoo to “neutral” with price targets of £24 and 200p respectively. The rise of online shopping and broader consumer choice has failed to boost industry revenue, with fast fashion growing at its slowest pace since the credit crunch, Merrill said.

Boohoo is facing competition from a second wave of disruptors, said Merrill, which identified 11 small brands in the UK that were taking on the clothes retailer directly. International competition has also strengthened, threatening Boohoo’s growth outside the core UK market, the broker said.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

(@DJ: not my highlighter.)

BE11:26am

It namechecks brands like Missguided, QUIZ, In The Style, Rebellious, Misspap, Public Desire, MissyEmpire, Girl Meets Dress and Oh Polly, all of which sound vaguely familiar.

BE11:26am

As well as a more fragmented, competitive and promotional environment, Boohoo likely faces rising shipment costs as its expansion is abroad while its logistics footprint is entirely in the UK, said Merrill. Its team also voiced concerns that Pretty Little Thing, the Boohoo’s fastest growing label, is only 66 per cent controlled by the group.

red @Excel Developerif they dont want it to take off and they don't, cpi probably won't take off. thats my guess
11:27 am
BE11:27am

On Asos, Merrill said the stock was “priced for perfection, but we now see margin recovery as increasingly unlikely”. It cited “unavoidable” promotional activity and a clustering of revenues around sales periods such as Black Friday.

“The retail market is becoming fragmented as barriers to scale fade,” said Merrill, whose analysis identified ten brands competing directly with the Asos own label in the UK. And with European retailer inventories piling up post Christmas, the high street stores will also compete aggressively for growth, it said.

Merrill forecast Asos margins to weaken 2.5 percentage points over the next three years. It expected the company to reset targets for its US division due to more onerous import tariffs, a higher reliance on third-party labels than in Europe, and potential price cuts to compensate consumers for sales taxes. At an 80 per cent premium to peers, Asos’s valuation “looks inflated”, it said.

ASOS PLC (ASC:LSE): Last: 2,894, down 228.43 (-7.32%), High: 3,066, Low: 2,876, Volume: 624.54k
Boohoo Group PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 188.38, down 5.78 (-2.97%), High: 194.00, Low: 188.00, Volume: 2.29m
11:27 am

red the bigger part of the pie online retail becomes, the more they are going to eat at each other rather than the street, that's basic economics
red @Excel Developerdepends on how you measure your inflation, but yes, on their terms its likely enough for now.

Pharma @Soundbuy, does that count as invocation of Goodwin's law, so we can all go home?

Shares up 14% live.

Excel Developer @PBateman: link?

BE11:32am

Carlyle, the US private equity firm, has joined a growing list of buyout houses considering a €4bn-plus takeover bid for Germany’s Osram, the lighting technology group that was spun out of industrial behemoth Siemens five years ago.

Carlyle’s interest was confirmed by two people with direct knowledge of the situation, who cautioned that there was no certainty the company would follow through with a firm offer. One of these people said Carlyle was taking a “preliminary look” which was at an early stage.

Carlyle declined to comment.

PBateman & now can't stand on it's own 2 feet without it
11:32 am
BE11:32am

Which is from mid December.

red osram a good opportunist buy
PBateman Really interesting how quick this slowdown has taken hold
BE11:33am

Bain had been named in November: https://www.ft.com...-9623-d7f9881e729f

cheeckychappy @BE - nothing like a good incremental development on an M&A story to keep a deal hack in a job...
BE11:33am

Let me get some valuation work here to pad it out.

chad_john FYI there's an excellent China fraud documentary on Netflix called 'The China Hustle' - well worth a watch.
chad_john It'll make you fall in love with shorters all over again.
11:33 am
BE11:34am

SocGen:

Excel Developer I think ECB is messing up, it wants to join the normalisation (of monetary policy) party along with the Fed but the fundamentals are indicating weaknesses implying a looser stance.
cheeckychappy Has anybody watched that Fyre festival Netflix doc?
BE11:34am

We retain our €32 TP which values Osram on 12.4x 2020e EBITA, vs
tech/LED peers on c.10-14x. Osram offers an attractive gearing to secular growth trends in autos. But a clouded near-term demand outlook, downside risks to consensus and guidance and weaker FCF prospects more than offset this long-term attraction. There is no visibility on
the speculated takeover bid for Osram, its valuations are expensive, and
an earnings bottom is not yet in sight.

chad_john CC - yes. It made me hate influencers all over again.
chad_john Send in the Evian guy to sort Brexit out.
BE11:35am

And UBS.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

We think that the LBO mathematics that would have supported a valuation in the mid 40s range have deteriorated sharply since we first wrote about it early December with our adj EBITDA estimate having come down by €80m (14%) since.

PBateman Someone tell Draghi to fire up the printing presses again
wayneJ Just what private equity needs to do - buy a heavily invested large German co. with slowing sales and 'restructure' by selling the hidden real estate and moving production to Eastern Europe / Asia. And cut R&D. Then lever up and float in 5 years. And walk away before u find in year 7 that the lack of R&D means u have no differentiated products. (Of course all the modelling will be 5 + 2 but in reality it will be 7 + 9)
BE11:35am

Based on the fact that real Q1 underlying performance was even worse than we expected (due to a much lower IFRS 15 impact) and given our rather muted short term auto market expectations we have cut our FY19 lfl sales growth forecast to -4% from -1% (guidance of positive 0-3% lfl growth). We now expect adj. EBITDA of €487m against €524m previously (7% cut) for a margin of 12.9% against guidance of 12- 14%. We have also cut FY20E adj. EBITDA by 7%. The cuts to our EPS estimates are much bigger given that our EPS are not adjusted for restructuring charges where our estimate has doubled. We see FCF at €76m vs guidance of a mid-single digit € amount.

BE11:35am

We value Osram based on a sum-of-the-parts model (EV/EBIT and EV/sales multiples). Our price target of €37 is unchanged as rolling our valuation forward to FY20E and lifting the multiple for Opto (from 11.0x to 14.3x) offsets our lower earnings estimates.

Shinshin @chad saw a good gag today that UK gov should extradite El Chapo and put him in dexeu as he seems to be very successful at friction free international trade
11:35 am
undefined
chad_john It's a better strategy than anything else they've got...
BE11:36am

Speaking of M&A, some interesting comments from Jones Lang LaSalle during its post-earnings call yesterday.

BE11:37am

In addition to the usual "We continue to be active and opportunistic in considering acquisitions" stuff ....

Excel Developer #ECB @PBateman: probably LTROs and TLTROs first before any resumption of outright asset purchases, to save the Germans blushes
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Christian Ulbrich's the speaker ....

Pharma @cheeckychappy #fyre, there is an interesting link about that film in Further Reading - suggests it is a whitewash to cover for role of some of the promoters.
BE11:38am

At least in my career, I've never seen a market which has so many availabilities with regards to M&A as it currently has. I think that's probably quite normal. We are on a late cycle moment in a long upturned swing, and so a lot of companies are currently interested in finding a new home. And so we have quite a lot of work going on in analyzing the different opportunities. But we have been pretty clear which areas are of interest to us at our Investor Day, and that hasn't really changed.
With regards to multiples, great companies are expecting a strong multiple, and less-than-great companies, we are not interested in. And so that's the obvious squeeze. On the one hand, you don't want to overpay. On the other hand, you only want to buy really outstanding companies who are a good fit for JLL.

red @Excel Developerto avoid a return to easing path they need a soft or no brexit. otherwise the growth just wont be there and the currency effect will also have a knock on to inflation rate
BE11:39am

That kind of thing. Surprised to see not much speculation around European names on the back of that.

11:39 am
undefined
BE11:39am

Smurfit!

Smurfit Kappa Group PLC (SKG:LSE): Last: 2,338, up 72 (+3.18%), High: 2,344, Low: 2,276, Volume: 506.96k
11:39 am
BE11:39am

It's a beat at earnings, a miss at revenue and a nonexistent outlook statement.

BE11:39am

They've been going for price rather than volume.

Excel Developer @red: oh that's interesting, perhaps that explains why they are holding off, there is binary event brewing. hmmm...
BE11:40am

And the numbers are confused because of Venezuela.

chad_john There was a link floating around on LinkedIn from various sources with the original pitch deck for Fyre. It's a masterclass in utter bullsh1t.
11:40 am
BE11:40am

Have Goldman.

red @Excel Developerthe cover is that they dont want draghi doing anything that with tie hands of his replacement later this year...
wayneJ If I recall Digby was actually a Birmingham solicitor rather than a business man who actually built a real (manufacturing) or international business from scratch.
BE11:41am

Overall we view the results as mixed. FY EBITDA came in 1% ahead of GSe and consensus despite missing on revenue, which is a small positive in our view. The miss on net income is driven by the consolidation of Venezuela; however this is a non-cash effect. We expect the company will add details to the limited outlook comments especially around volume and price expectations as well as direction of key cost. Over the past one month SKG shares are up 7% vs our Paper and Packaging coverage up 6% and Stoxx 600 up 4%.

Key points
2H18 adjusted EBITDA came in at €821m, 2%/1% above GSe of €801m and
Bloomberg consensus of €812m.
Divisionally, Europe came in ahead of our expectations while Americas came in below Net debt came in at €3.1bn (GSe definition) vs GSe of €3.3bn.

Total dividend of 0.967 cents per share (which implies second half dividend of 0.722 cents) was announced vs GSe of €0.93 per share and BBG consensus of €0.95 per share
Guidance
Limited outlook comments were given, Smurfit highlighted macro uncertainties, but also that the business is “well positioned to capitalize on industry opportunities”.
Capex was guided to be €600-700mn (GSe €659mn for 2019), cash interest was guided to be €160mn, cash tax €240mn, tax rate 27%
IFRS 16 will impact EBITDA positively by around 5%, increase ND by 11-12%, and decrease ROCE by ~1%

Excel Developer @red: copy that
BE11:42am

And Davy.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

The outlook statement is brief with management indicating that the year “has started positively”. Prices for both recycled containerboard (RCB) and kraftliner were down in Q4 leaving RCB prices flat yoy, while kraftliner prices were still up yoy. We do not believe that the fall in containerboard prices to date will be sufficient to materially impact corrugated prices.
We are forecasting EBITDA for 2019 of €1629m, implying yoy growth of €84m. Over €60m of this is from acquisitions, implying underlying growth of €22m or just over 1%. More significantly, we are forecasting free cashflow of almost €550m or €750m assuming ‘normal’ capex. This implies a ‘normalised’ free cashflow yield of over 12% with net debt/EBITDA falling to sub-1.7x, below the lower end of the company’s guided 1.75-2.5x.

BE11:42am

And Citi.

BE11:42am

The results themselves should be well received by the market. The
medium-term plan appears to be on track, and cash and dividend growth are good. Box volume growth was below expectations and could support fears that demand will be weak through 2019. We see significant upside for the stock at current levels, based on the strong underlying earnings for the group and solid positioning in the sustainability megatrends. We rate Smurfit Buy.

11:42 am
undefined

I seem to be alone in being fascinated by journals publishing, which is far far far far more complicated and feudal than it looks. However, no one else is so let's move on.

(@Wayne: just a cut-paste of Spire stuff. Had already linked to it above, hence zap. Nothing interesting.)

Pharma @Shinshin, they own copyright on the formatting. Academics retain joint copyright on the text and figures for non-commercial use.
wayneJ @Shinshin - nah - this used to drive me mad - the journals own the rights. So you can publish a paper in a prestigious journal and then have to pay to get a pdf to send to others.
BE11:56am

Miners ........ sorry, nothing much around today.

RiskyBoy Request for tomorrow please: RPS (down yesterday, up today, not a lot of news) hugely volatile.

DJ @BE @ROTR thanks all
Pharma @wayneJ you still in theory have to pay for the final pdf, but it is not enforced. The repositories that most western institutions have set up store submitted manuscripts, not formatted papers.
wayneJ @BE - thx. I have always wondered if only you have the zap button or if (Nigel?) the lawyers have a second one?
11:57 am

There's Galliford and Countrywide if we need DPL.

Here's Peel Hunt, shop broker:

Excel Developer @BE: I like academic journals and getting the raw academic reports, it's just they're so often paywalled.
11:58 am
BE11:59am

First half figures were a bit better than expected due to lower
interest, central costs and PPP disposals. Linden and
Partnerships combined matched last year’s profits, as did
Construction. The balance sheet has improved due to the net
balance of the rights monies less the road spend. Overall we are
leaving forecasts where they are for FY19-20 and retain our Buy
recommendation and 885p target price.

wayneJ @BE - the peer review of journals and editorial decision making is a serious art. A bit like newspapers - everything has a word processor so assumes that a newspaper is easy. Also why MSN / Google et al have news services that suck
BE11:59am

While there is a degree of uncertainty in the economy, management is confident that the business is on track for its 2021 targets and, as a result, we are not making any changes to our forecasts for FY19 or FY20. The Aberdeen road is now physically complete, but is waiting a final agreement on maintenance before the last leg over the river Don is opened. The discussion over the extra costs claim will then step up a gear and will hopefully lead to a settlement rather than a drawn-out arbitration process.

wayneJ On Healthcare - any view on NMC? Thinking that oil price and dynamics can't be good for middle eastern hospitals?
BE12:00pm

And Peel Hunt, not shop broker.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

The group has delivered FY18 profits in line with previously
reset guidance, and the rights issue – together with good control
of cash – led to year-end leverage of 2.2x. Management has
made little comment on current trading, though properties with
agreed sales awaiting exchange of contract are ahead by c5%
(against an easy comp last year). An update on the outlook and
FY19 guidance will be provided at the results next month. We
see no reason to change our forecasts at his stage. Hold.

BE12:00pm

That's on Countrywide, to be clear.

Countrywide PLC (CWD:LSE): Last: 10.08, up 0.2883 (+2.94%), High: 10.18, Low: 9.50, Volume: 1.17m
Excel Developer @BE: Do you recommend this, https://doaj.org/
wayneJ (Though London hospitals are suffering from Embassy volumes falling; also American brands are squeezing UK ones in Londinium. Plus some NHS hospitals upping their game).
12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

There is little comment from the group on current trading, though properties with agreed sales awaiting exchange of contract are ahead by c5% (against an easy comparative of -21% at the start of last year). Clearly it is a difficult overall trading backdrop in residential sales, though we expect lettings and the group’s other divisions to continue to provide relative resilience. An update on guidance for 2019 will be provided at the full-year results on March 7th. We leave our profit forecasts unchanged at this stage: our FY19 EBITDA forecast is £43m. The shares trade on an FY19 EV/Sales of 0.4x and EV/EBITDA of 5.8x.

Blank canvas thanks for everything today BE.
Soundbuy Cheers all.............and ta
Pharma @Excel if one of the authors is from a European or US university it is worth going to their employers website and looking for the research repository. Pretty much compulsory to deposit everything now. It will be harder to read, but be the same in all essentials.
Excel Developer @Pharma: ok, thanks.
wayneJ @Pharma - does that include the UK?
Viking1 Thanks BE
Pharma @wayneJ - yes, UK was one of the first.
Excel Developer @Pharma: and of course for economics, central banks' staff papers are free (and excellent)
Pharma @Excel, but who here would be interested in economics?
BE12:03pm

(@Excel: DOAJ's an interesting development among many. One of the main hurdles to adoption seems to be, to summarise, academics are weird. There's not much evidence supporting the assumption that the majority wants wider access.)

undefined
Excel Developer @BE: ok, ta.
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Are we done? I think we're done.

wayneJ @Pharma - thx
Excel Developer That DOAJ has a web service API, so one can programmatically trawl. Cool! https://doaj.org/api/v1/docs
Pharma @BE, the argument that the UK government should invest significant sums of money on open access so that my mum and her friends can read my research papers deserves more cost-benefit analysis.
VV75 ta

Ta for the comments. You can read everything you've read over here, if you want: https://www.ft.com/stocks-to-watch

It's kind of like ML's +1 channel.

A. M. (well, not all open-access journals are of equal quality)
